All or parts of these tests failed in precheckin.
```
org.apache.geode.cache.CacheXml70GatewayDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.distributed.ServerLauncherLocalFileIntegrationTest
org.apache.geode.distributed.ServerLauncherLocalIntegrationTest

org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedNoAckRegionDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DiskDistributedNoAckAsyncOverflowRegionDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DiskDistributedNoAckAsyncRegionDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DiskDistributedNoAckSyncOverflowRegionDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckOverflowRegionCCEDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckRegionCCEDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckRegionDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckPersistentRegionCCEDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckRegionCompressionDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckOverflowRegionCCEOffHeapDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckRegionCCEOffHeapDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckPersistentRegionCCEOffHeapDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedAckRegionOffHeapDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedNoAckRegionCCEOffHeapDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedNoAckRegionCCEDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DistributedNoAckRegionOffHeapDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.GlobalRegionDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.GlobalRegionCCEDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.GlobalRegionOffHeapDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.GlobalRegionCCEOffHeapDUnitTest
org.apache.geode.cache30.DynamicRegionDUnitTest
```

They are all failing for the same reason. CacheCreation.getIndexes was returning null. Since the check was removed, the tests were failing here:
```
java.lang.NullPointerException
  at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.xmlcache.CacheXmlGenerator.generate(CacheXmlGenerator.java:1668)
  at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.xmlcache.CacheXmlGenerator.generateRegion(CacheXmlGenerator.java:696)
  at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.xmlcache.CacheXmlGenerator.parse(CacheXmlGenerator.java:611)
```
I made a change to getIndexes to address this:
```
public Collection<Index> getIndexes(Region<?, ?> region) {
  return this.indexes.containsKey(region.getFullPath()) ? this.indexes.get(region.getFullPath())
    : Collections.emptyList();
}
```
After that fix, all the tests pass. Feel free to use this change or implement it however you want.

Thanks @boglesby,
I didn't receive any email for the failed `precheckin` (and I certainly don't run it locally because it takes ages to complete...), I'll need to look into that further.
That said, I'll make the suggested changes and push the changes later today.
Thanks again.

+1!

I'll leave the final word and merge up to the Spotless Czar :)

I had thought the appeal of a reentrant lock was that the lock could be cleanly and efficiently reacquired.  If we can programmatically enforce stability, even on the "it should be okay without it" methods, I think we should do that.

At the very least, it would be good to include a comment at the beginning of the four private methods or in their javadocs that warns future developers that these methods expect a write lock to have already been acquired.

precheckin is green
Can you explain why this change fixes the race? I see that you removed the volatile, and split the if statement on two lines. How does that help?
precheckin is green

There was race condition that hit the `if` statement where it was split where `serverSocket` was not null but before it got to the `&&`  the finally in `startTcpServer` set `serverSocker` to null.  The test case recreates this with some trickery.  @WireBaron might be able to give a more detailed answer than I can.
+1, agree with Dan's comments.  Both read and write ops must have synchronization to access shared state.

So, the root of the problem here is that there's a member variable keeping track of the socket which was being set to null in two different places (oddly so in one case).  The socket itself is thread-safe and properly handles concurrent access, so we're not concerned about multiple threads trying to close this.

The real fix here is just the removal of line 734.  With this gone, the nulling of the local variable is only done in the StopServices call and the race condition goes away.  It seems like the volatile is no longer necessary as this variable is no longer being accessed by multiple threads (curiously, with the exception of line 734, the other thread only accessed the socket through a separate local variable), but I'll go ahead and add it back in just to minimize the chances for unintended consequences.
I am very much in favor of not nulling out instance variables.  Doing so frequently leads to null pointer exceptions like this.
precheckin green
Agreed, removed the null assignment.
We found that the RegionDestroyedException shouldn't be thrown under normal operation during the commit, so handling it there is not the best solution.

@balesh2
@gesterzhou  ^

Hi,

OOB this function is disabled -
if (distributionConfigImpl.getThreadMonitorAutoEnabled()
        && this.numIterationsStuck > distributionConfigImpl.getThreadMonitorAutoLimit())
      handleInterrupt();

also, if enabled, we kill the thread only after it is stuck for very long time (OOB – 1[min](interval)*200 = 200[min])

Thanks,
Yossi Reginiano

From: Bruce Schuchardt [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Monday, June 04, 2018 11:51 PM
To: apache/geode
Cc: Yossi Reginiano; Author
Subject: Re: [apache/geode] Thread Monitoring Mechanism GEODE-5142 (#1868)


@bschuchardt requested changes on this pull request.

I like the sentiment here but this looks like a dangerous change. It is putting a fixed time limit on execution of arbitrary jobs with no real check to see if threads are stuck or not. If a thread is doing some heavy lifting it could be killed with Thread.stop() in the middle of its work. Think initial image transfer, for instance. This can also leave threads stuck waiting for replies until they, too, are killed.

Killing threads without knowing what they're really doing could result in data corruption when updating cache values or disk stores. We've seen this before when Thread.interrupt() was used to stop arbitrary threads in an unknown state during shutdown and we stopped doing that.

I'm against this being merged. If it were changed into a diagnostic tool by getting rid of Thread.stop() I'd look at it again, but I'm not sure it would be much more helpful than a couple of thread dumps.

—

-1

I agree with @PivotalSarge and @bschuchardt.  `Thread.stop()` is scheduled to be removed at some point.  It's unsafe because it leaves the system an in indeterminate state.  See these links:

http://cr.openjdk.java.net/~iris/se/10/fr/java-se-10-fr-spec/#APIs-proposed-for-removal
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/concurrency/threadPrimitiveDeprecation.html
+1 with Karen's suggestions.

Hi Galen,

Thanks for your review
I will work on the changes u requested – as we prefer to have the option of kill thread available for us, I will try to implement it with a callback as u suggested
For the third bullet – did u mean to put the entire thread monitor classes in a new package? Something like -  org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.threadMonitor ?

Thanks,
Yossi Reginiano

From: galen-pivotal [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Tuesday, June 05, 2018 9:35 PM
To: apache/geode
Cc: Yossi Reginiano; Author
Subject: Re: [apache/geode] Thread Monitoring Mechanism GEODE-5142 (#1868)


@galen-pivotal requested changes on this pull request.

I agree that Thread.stop() absolutely should not be used -- it can result in an exception being thrown almost anywhere and lead to inconsistency in state. It may be useful to detect hangs and do something about them, but we have to rely on some coordination from the thread process. If you wanted the Thread.stop() behaviour and were not worried about data inconsistency, perhaps you could put a callback in the monitor to register such.

Besides that, I have a few concerns about the code:

  *   AbstractExecutorGroup actually refers to a single thread; ThreadMonitoring is what monitors a group. The names seem wrong.
  *   setIsThreadStuck is named like a boolean but takes an int
  *   We should move this to its own package, reduce visibility, and be very clear about what the public API for this for the monitoring package is. For example, setThreadMonitoringProcess / getThreadMonitoringProcess.

In general, I also think it's a good practice to make as many fields final as possible, so that it's clear what can change.

—

precheckin green again.

This solution may ignore events that should not have been ignored when the first node goes down before returning an exception that the entry does not exist. The client then retries on another node and we ignore that the entry does not exist and pretend we destroyed it.

following requested changes were done-

1. Thread.stop() was removed
2. classes names were updated as recommended
3. setIsThreadStuck & getIsThreadStuck were updated to support integer rather than Boolean
4. ThreadsMonitoring was moved to its own package and visibility (as possible) was reduced. also as many fields as possible were moved to be final
